intro: This wikiHow teaches you how to start playing Minecraft on a computer, a smartphone or tablet, or a console. Once you've purchased, downloaded, and/or installed Minecraft, you can create a new world to start exploring and experiencing Minecraft's features.

steps.title: Know the different kinds of mobs.
steps.subtitle: While you may be tempted to run away from every animal and monster that you see, most mobs won't attack you unless you attack first:
sub-points: - These mobs will never attack you, though they will flee if you attack them. Examples include most livestock (pigs, cows, sheep, etc.).
- These mobs will not attack you unless you attack first. Examples include Endermen and Spiders (day only).
- These mobs will always attack on sight. Examples include Zombies, Skeletons, and Spiders (night only).

steps.title: Avoid fighting mobs if possible.
steps.subtitle: Minecraft is not a combat-centric game; while you have the means to craft items with which you can defend yourself, actively going out and attempting to kill mobs is more likely to result in your death than in you surviving the night. While there will always be exceptions to this rule (e.g., if you have to kill a spider for some string), running away from conflict is always better than entertaining it in Minecraft.
sub-points: If you must fight mobs, you'll want to use a sword or an axe to do so; other tools are more effective than using your bare fists, however.
Creepers (the green exploding monsters) are best left alone. If one begins pursuing you, hit it once and then retreat until it explodes.
Endermen (the tall black figures) will not attack you if you avoid looking at them or hitting them. If provoked, Endermen will prove incredibly tough to kill with any equipment.
If you have a bow and some arrows, you can usually attack enemies while backpedaling. Keep in mind that some mobs (e.g., Skeletons) also have bows and arrows.
